data.title: 100 Best Dance Songs of the 2000s
data.meta_description: The 2000s was a decade that brought about some of the most memorable and influential dance songs of all time. From electronic beats to pop-infused anthems, the era was a melting pot of musical styles that united people of all ages and backgrounds on the dance floor. With iconic artists like Beyoncé, Rihanna, Justin Timberlake,
data.meta_site_name: Singersroom.com - R&B Music, R&B Videos, R&B News
data.text:
The 2000s was a decade that brought about some of the most memorable and influential dance songs of all time. From electronic beats to pop-infused anthems, the era was a melting pot of musical styles that united people of all ages and backgrounds on the dance floor. With iconic artists like Beyoncé, Rihanna, Justin Timberlake, and Lady Gaga taking the lead, the 2000s saw the rise of electronic dance music, the emergence of new dance genres, and the continuation of classic disco and funk sounds. The decade was also marked by an increase in music streaming and digital downloads, allowing for wider access to music and further promoting dance music culture worldwide.

In this article, we will explore the top 100 best dance songs of the 2000s. These songs were selected based on their impact on the dance music scene, their chart success, and their ability to get people moving and grooving on the dance floor. We will take a trip down memory lane and revisit some of the most iconic dance hits of the decade, from club bangers to party anthems, and everything in between. So put on your dancing shoes and get ready to relive the best dance music moments of the 2000s.

1. One More Time – Daft Punk

Daft Punk’s “One More Time” is an iconic dance track that perfectly captures the essence of the 2000s electronic music scene. Released in 2000, the song features a funky disco beat and a catchy hook that will keep you on the dancefloor all night long. The track’s use of vocoder effects and Daft Punk’s signature robot personas add a futuristic touch to the timeless disco sound. “One More Time” is a quintessential party anthem that has stood the test of time and continues to inspire dance music lovers around the world.

2. Just Dance – Lady Gaga feat. Colby O’Donis

“Just Dance” is a vibrant and infectious dance-pop hit by Lady Gaga, featuring Colby O’Donis. Released in 2008, it became Gaga’s first-ever single to top the Billboard Hot 100, launching her into global stardom. The song’s upbeat tempo, pulsating beats, and catchy chorus make it an irresistible dancefloor anthem. Gaga’s commanding vocals, along with O’Donis’ smooth rap verses, bring an undeniable energy to the track that keeps the listener hooked from start to finish. The lyrics, about letting go of one’s inhibitions and getting lost in the music, perfectly encapsulate the carefree spirit of dance music. “Just Dance” has become a classic party song and is still played at clubs and events around the world, making it an enduring symbol of the late 2000s dance scene.

3. Music – Madonna

Madonna’s “Music” is a vibrant dance-pop anthem that dominated the charts in the early 2000s. The song’s pulsating beat, catchy melody, and electrifying lyrics make it a classic party track. Madonna’s signature voice is in top form as she sings about the power of music to bring people together and ignite a sense of joy and freedom. The song’s futuristic production, with its heavy use of electronic beats and synths, perfectly captures the technological optimism of the early 2000s. “Music” is a testament to Madonna’s legendary status as an icon of pop culture and her ability to constantly reinvent herself and stay relevant. Whether you’re on the dance floor or in your car, “Music” is a song that never fails to get you moving and feeling alive.

4. Can’t Get You Out of My Head – Kylie Minogue

“Can’t Get You Out of My Head” is a dance-pop classic by Australian singer Kylie Minogue, released in 2001. The song was written and produced by Cathy Dennis and Rob Davis, and became a massive hit worldwide, reaching number one in over 40 countries. The infectious melody and catchy hook of the song have made it a dancefloor staple, and its sleek production and Minogue’s sultry vocals have made it a fan favorite. The music video for the song features Minogue in various futuristic outfits, adding to the song’s overall sleek and modern feel. “Can’t Get You Out of My Head” has been widely praised for its pop sensibility and its ability to get people moving on the dancefloor, cementing it as a beloved classic of the 2000s dance music scene.

5. Finally – Kings of Tomorrow feat. Julie McKnight

“Finally” by Kings of Tomorrow feat. Julie McKnight is a classic dance anthem that has stood the test of time. Released in 2000, the track features a soulful and uplifting vocal performance from McKnight set to a house beat that builds and drops with impeccable precision. The song’s catchy chorus, “Time marches on, never-ending, time keeps its own time,” has become a memorable sing-along for dance music fans everywhere. The track’s timeless appeal is evident in its continued popularity in DJ sets and on dance floors around the world. “Finally” has become a beloved staple in the house music genre and is recognized as one of the best dance tracks of the 2000s.

6. Groovejet (If This Ain’t Love) – Spiller feat. Sophie Ellis-Bextor

Released in 2000, “Groovejet (If This Ain’t Love)” by Italian DJ Spiller featuring British singer Sophie Ellis-Bextor became one of the biggest dance hits of the decade. The song topped the UK charts for four consecutive weeks and won the prestigious Ivor Novello Award for Best Dance Anthem. The upbeat disco-house track is characterized by its funky bassline, catchy vocal hooks, and pulsing beats that never fail to get people on the dance floor. Ellis-Bextor’s soulful voice adds an element of sophistication to the song and perfectly complements the infectious rhythm. “Groovejet” paved the way for the popularity of disco-house in the early 2000s and remains a beloved dance classic to this day.

7. Lady (Hear Me Tonight) – Modjo

“Lady (Hear Me Tonight)” is a French house song by Modjo that was released in 2000. The track features an infectious and upbeat rhythm that was instantly popular with club-goers and dance music fans. The song is characterized by its catchy guitar riff, groovy bassline, and soulful vocals that exclaim “Lady, hear me tonight, cos my feeling is just so right.” The upbeat and energetic tempo of the song makes it impossible not to dance along to, and the chorus is easy to sing along with. “Lady (Hear Me Tonight)” went on to become a global hit, reaching the top of the charts in several countries and earning Modjo multiple accolades. The song is often credited with helping to popularize the French house genre and continues to be a staple of dance parties and DJ sets to this day.

8. Toca’s Miracle – Fragma

“Toca’s Miracle” is an energetic dance track by German electronic music group Fragma, featuring the soulful vocals of British singer Coco Star. Originally released in 1999, the song gained widespread popularity in the early 2000s, particularly in the UK where it reached number one on the singles chart. The song features a sample from the 1993 song “I Need a Miracle” by the group Coco, which was a hit in the UK club scene. The infectious beat and uplifting melody of “Toca’s Miracle” have made it a dancefloor classic, with its distinctive vocal hook and anthemic chorus. The song’s success helped cement Fragma’s status as one of the leading dance acts of the early 2000s, and its influence can still be felt in modern electronic dance music.

9. Hung Up – Madonna

Madonna’s “Hung Up” is a vibrant and energetic dance-pop anthem that became an instant classic upon its release in 2005. The song’s driving beat and infectious hook draw listeners in and make it nearly impossible not to dance along. The lyrics, which touch on themes of love and loss, are delivered with passion and urgency by Madonna, who showcases her vocal range in the song’s soaring chorus. The use of a sample from ABBA’s “Gimme! Gimme! Gimme! (A Man After Midnight)” adds a nostalgic touch to the track and gives it a timeless quality that continues to resonate with audiences today. “Hung Up” cemented Madonna’s status as a pop icon and remains one of her most popular and beloved songs.

10. Poker Face – Lady Gaga

“Poker Face” is a dance-pop song by Lady Gaga that was released in 2008. The song was written by Lady Gaga and RedOne, and it became a worldwide hit, topping the charts in several countries. The song features a catchy chorus and a pulsating dance beat that is hard to resist. The lyrics describe Lady Gaga’s poker face, which she uses to hide her true emotions while playing a game of love. The song’s popularity was helped by its catchy hook and the music video, which featured Lady Gaga dancing in a variety of outfits, including a futuristic metallic bodysuit. “Poker Face” has become one of Lady Gaga’s signature songs and is often played at her concerts. It has also been covered by several artists and has been used in movies and TV shows. Overall, “Poker Face” is a fun and energetic dance-pop song that is sure to get people moving on the dance floor.

11. Romeo – Basement Jaxx

“Romeo” by Basement Jaxx is an electronic dance track that was released in 2001. The song features a catchy beat and a powerful chorus that is sure to get people moving on the dance floor. The track blends different genres such as house, disco, and funk to create a unique and energetic sound. The lyrics are simple but effective, with the repeated phrase “Where’s your head at?” creating a memorable hook. The use of horns and synths in the instrumental gives the track a sense of grandeur, while the driving rhythm section keeps the energy high throughout the song. “Romeo” was a massive hit upon its release, reaching the top ten in several countries and earning critical acclaim for its innovative sound. The song remains a classic of the electronic dance music genre, and its influence can still be heard in modern dance music today.

12. Satisfaction – Benny Benassi

Benny Benassi’s “Satisfaction” is a pulsating electronic dance track that became a massive hit in the early 2000s. The driving bassline, catchy vocal samples, and infectious beat make it a must-play in any dance club or party. The repetitive and hypnotic nature of the track gives it a timeless quality that still resonates with audiences today. “Satisfaction” is a perfect example of the power of a well-crafted dance track and the ability of music to unite people on the dance floor. It’s an undeniable classic that continues to influence the electronic dance music genre.

13. Heaven – DJ Sammy & Yanou feat. Do

“Heaven” is an emotional dance track that features the captivating vocals of Do, along with the signature sounds of DJ Sammy and Yanou. Released in 2002, the song quickly became a hit, reaching the top of the charts in several countries. The song is a cover of a ballad originally released by Bryan Adams in 1985, but DJ Sammy and Yanou transformed it into a dance anthem with a driving beat and a memorable melody. The lyrics tell a story of longing and yearning for a lost love, which is reflected in Do’s powerful and emotive delivery. The song’s soaring chorus and infectious hook make it a perfect addition to any dancefloor playlist.

14. Rapture – Iio

“Iio” stands for “International Ignition Operation,” and the duo made quite the splash in the dance music world with their 2001 single, “Rapture.” The song is a fusion of house and trance elements, highlighted by lead vocalist Nadia Ali’s angelic voice. The lyrics are both dreamy and evocative, telling the story of a powerful love that takes the singer on an emotional journey. The synth-heavy melody and Ali’s soaring vocals make “Rapture” an instant classic, and it’s no surprise that it quickly became an international hit. The song has been remixed and covered numerous times, but the original remains a staple of dance music playlists.

15. Touch Me – Rui Da Silva

“Touch Me” is a classic dance track by Portuguese DJ and producer Rui Da Silva, featuring vocals from British singer Cassandra Fox. Released in 2001, the song features a catchy melody, uplifting beats and soulful vocals that make it a popular choice on dance floors around the world. The track is built around a sample from the 1993 song “Are You There?” by Josh Wink, which is used as the basis for the infectious riff that runs throughout the song. Fox’s vocals provide a touch of emotional depth to the track, as she sings about the longing for human connection and the desire to be touched. The song’s music video features a group of people dancing in a club, with flashes of the main characters experiencing moments of emotional connection. “Touch Me” became a huge commercial success, reaching the top of the charts in several countries, and has since become a staple of dance music culture.

16. D.A.N.C.E. – Justice

“D.A.N.C.E.” by Justice is a funky and catchy dance song that quickly became a favorite in the mid-2000s. The song’s upbeat tempo and energetic vocals create a fun and lively atmosphere that is sure to get people on their feet. The French duo behind the song masterfully combines electronic beats with a retro sound, making it a unique and memorable hit. The song’s infectious hook and easy-to-remember lyrics make it a classic dance anthem that is still played in clubs and parties today. “D.A.N.C.E.” is a prime example of Justice’s ability to create a sound that seamlessly blends modern electronic music with vintage pop and disco influences.

17. Call On Me – Eric Prydz

“Call On Me” by Eric Prydz is an upbeat dance track that became a worldwide hit in the mid-2000s. The song samples the 1982 hit “Valerie” by Steve Winwood and adds a pulsating electronic beat that makes it impossible to resist dancing to. The accompanying music video features a group of women exercising in a suggestive manner, which adds to the song’s appeal. “Call On Me” became a popular choice for workouts and aerobics classes, and its catchy melody and high-energy beats made it a club favorite. The song’s success helped to establish Eric Prydz as one of the leading names in the world of electronic dance music.

18. Dragostea Din Tei (Mi Ya Hi) – O-Zone

“Dragostea Din Tei (Mi Ya Hi)” is an infectious dance-pop song that took the world by storm in the early 2000s. The Romanian group O-Zone’s hit features catchy lyrics that are sung in a mix of Romanian, Spanish, and English. The upbeat melody, coupled with the infectious chorus, makes this song an instant dancefloor hit. The catchy tune became a global sensation, topping the charts in multiple countries and even inspiring numerous parodies and remixes. Whether you are looking to reminisce about the early 2000s or just in the mood for a fun, upbeat tune, “Dragostea Din Tei (Mi Ya Hi)” is sure to get you grooving.

19. House of Jealous Lovers – The Rapture

“House of Jealous Lovers” by The Rapture is a dance-punk anthem that quickly became a cult classic. The song’s energetic beat, funky bassline, and catchy vocal hooks create a thrilling, frenzied atmosphere that is hard to resist. The Rapture’s combination of dance music and punk rock influences makes this song unique and instantly recognizable. The group’s raw, stripped-down sound and urgent lyrics give “House of Jealous Lovers” a sense of urgency and excitement that sets it apart from other dance tracks. The song’s repetitive chorus and relentless groove make it a perfect choice for club DJs and dance parties, and its enduring popularity is a testament to its status as a classic of the genre.

20. All My Friends – LCD Soundsystem

“All My Friends” by LCD Soundsystem is an indie dance-rock track that was released in 2007. The song features a driving beat, infectious piano chords, and melancholic lyrics that explore the experience of growing older and feeling disconnected from one’s youth. The song has been praised for its emotional depth, relatable themes, and catchy instrumentation. The lead singer’s voice captures the sense of longing and nostalgia that the song conveys, making it a standout track from the band’s discography. The track was a critical success, earning spots on many “Best of” lists and becoming a fan favorite. It has been covered and sampled by other artists, and remains a beloved track in the indie rock and dance music scenes.

21. Since I Left You – Avalanches

“Since I Left You” by Avalanches is a cheerful and captivating dance song that blends a wide range of samples to create a dynamic and unique sound. The song’s beat is infectious, and the catchy lyrics combined with the diverse samples used in the song create an upbeat and lively atmosphere. The Avalanches used over 3,500 samples to create the album “Since I Left You,” and this song is a testament to their incredible sampling skills. The song’s nostalgic and dreamlike quality is sure to get people up and dancing, making it a perfect choice for a party playlist. Overall, “Since I Left You” is a creative and captivating dance song that showcases the unique sound and talent of the Avalanches.

22. Archangel – Burial

“Archangel” by Burial is a hauntingly beautiful electronic track that blends elements of UK garage and dubstep. The track is built around a sample from the song “I Can’t Stand the Rain” by Ann Peebles, which is chopped up and manipulated to create a hypnotic, otherworldly melody. The beats are crisp and minimal, with subtle percussion and a deep, rumbling bassline that adds weight and depth to the track. The overall effect is mesmerizing, with a sense of melancholy and longing that is both powerful and elusive. Burial is known for his innovative and experimental approach to electronic music, and “Archangel” is a prime example of his ability to create music that is both atmospheric and emotional. The track has become a classic of the genre and continues to influence electronic musicians around the world.

23. Heartbeats – The Knife

“Heartbeats” by The Knife is a hauntingly beautiful electronic pop song that captures the essence of the 2000s indie music scene. The song is characterized by its gentle electronic melody, ethereal vocals, and minimalist yet deeply moving lyrics. The Knife’s signature use of synthesizers and electronic percussion is on full display, creating a mesmerizing soundscape that is both futuristic and nostalgic. The song’s chorus is particularly memorable, with its soaring harmonies and introspective lyrics about the fragile nature of love and relationships. “Heartbeats” is a timeless masterpiece that continues to captivate listeners with its dreamy, otherworldly vibe.

24. Over And Over – Hot Chip

“Over And Over” is an energetic electro-pop track by the British band Hot Chip. Released in 2006, the song features a catchy synth riff and a danceable beat that will keep your feet moving. The vocals are delivered in a style that is both playful and heartfelt, with lyrics that convey a sense of longing and repetition. The song builds up gradually to a euphoric climax that will leave you wanting more. “Over And Over” is a perfect example of Hot Chip’s ability to create dance music that is both infectious and emotionally resonant, and has become one of their most popular songs.

25. Miura – Metro Area

“Miura” by Metro Area is a captivating song that takes the listener on a mesmerizing journey through its retro-infused, house music. The track features a catchy bassline that is beautifully complemented by a variety of synthesized sounds and percussion, making it an instant dancefloor hit. The steady rhythm is perfectly balanced with occasional vocals, giving it a sense of a story being told through music. The song has an uplifting and energetic vibe that makes it perfect for both relaxing and partying. With its unique sound and irresistible beat, “Miura” continues to be a favorite among electronic music lovers.

26. Midnight Request Line – Skream

“Midnight Request Line” by Skream is a defining track in the genre of dubstep. It features a haunting melody and deep, wobbling bass that creates a moody and atmospheric vibe. The song’s title is a reference to the late-night phone calls requesting music that were common in the early days of dubstep. The track is known for its distinctive sound design and use of negative space, creating tension and release through its sparse arrangement. “Midnight Request Line” helped to popularize dubstep beyond its underground roots and is considered a classic of the genre.

27. Destination Calabria – Alex Gaudino feat. Crystal Waters

“Destination Calabria” by Alex Gaudino featuring Crystal Waters is a dance-pop song with a pulsing beat that is impossible to resist. The track was released in 2007 and quickly became a hit on dance floors worldwide. With its catchy hook, “Destination Calabria” is the perfect anthem for partying and dancing all night long. Crystal Waters’ vocals add a touch of soul to the track, making it even more infectious. The song’s title is a reference to the region of Calabria in Italy, which is known for its stunning beaches and vibrant nightlife. “Destination Calabria” captures the spirit of a summer vacation in the Mediterranean, where the party never stops. The track’s upbeat tempo and driving bassline make it a classic dance floor filler that continues to be played in clubs and festivals to this day.

28. Something – Lasgo

“Something” by Lasgo is an uplifting dance track that gained popularity in the early 2000s. The song features catchy synth hooks and pulsing beats that build to a euphoric chorus. The vocals by lead singer Jelle van Dael soar above the infectious instrumentation, delivering lyrics about the power of love to lift us up and carry us through difficult times. “Something” has a nostalgic appeal for fans of early 2000s dance music, but its uplifting message and infectious energy make it a timeless dancefloor favorite.

29. Castles In The Sky – Ian Van Dahl

“Ian Van Dahl” was a Belgian trance music project formed in 2000, and “Castles in the Sky” was their most popular track. This song features an upbeat and energetic tempo with a driving beat, catchy synth hooks, and beautiful vocals from Marsha. The lyrics speak about a place where dreams can come true and where the sky meets the sea. The chorus is particularly memorable, with Marsha’s vocals soaring high as she sings the iconic hook, “Do you ever question your life? Do you ever wonder why? Do you ever see in your dreams, all the castles in the sky?” Overall, “Castles in the Sky” is a quintessential example of early 2000s trance music and continues to be a beloved classic in the genre.

30. Night – Benga & Coki

Benga & Coki’s “Night” is a classic dubstep track that perfectly captures the essence of the genre. The song features a hauntingly beautiful melody that is both menacing and seductive. The bassline is deep and powerful, with a wobbly, distorted sound that will rattle your bones. The percussion is sparse but effective, with a skittering snare and clattering hi-hats that give the track a sense of urgency. The drops are pure dubstep bliss, with the bassline hitting hard and fast, leaving you breathless and wanting more. “Night” is a timeless classic that will make you fall in love with dubstep all over again.

31. Everytime We Touch – Cascada

“Everytime We Touch” by Cascada is an upbeat dance-pop anthem that became a massive hit in the mid-2000s. The song features driving beats, soaring synths, and powerful vocals that deliver an irresistible hook that will have you singing along in no time. The lyrics describe the overwhelming feeling of falling in love and the intense emotions that come with it. The song’s catchy chorus and energetic production have made it a staple in dance clubs and parties, with its infectious melody and high-energy beats leaving listeners feeling euphoric and wanting more.

32. Bad Romance – Lady Gaga

“Bad Romance” by Lady Gaga is a modern pop classic that features Gaga’s signature blend of catchy hooks, quirky lyrics, and infectious beats. The song opens with a haunting melody and builds into a pounding electronic dance anthem. The chorus, with its instantly recognizable “Ra-ra-ah-ah-ah, roma-roma-ma, Gaga, ooh la-la” hook, is a singalong favorite. The lyrics tell the story of a toxic love affair, with Gaga singing about being “caught in a bad romance” and “wanting your love, but also needing your revenge.” The song’s music video is an iconic visual feast, featuring Gaga in a range of outlandish costumes and avant-garde makeup.

33. Days Go By – Dirty Vegas

“Days Go By” is a dance-infused electronic track by British band Dirty Vegas. It features a catchy beat with pulsating synths, and lead vocalist Steve Smith’s smooth vocals gliding over the instrumentation. The song’s lyrics about moving on and letting go of the past add an emotional depth to the upbeat track. “Days Go By” became a huge success upon its release, earning the band a Grammy Award for Best Dance Recording in 2003. It remains a staple in the electronic music scene, known for its infectious melody and uplifting energy.

34. Where’s Your Head At? – Basement Jaxx

“Where’s Your Head At?” by Basement Jaxx is a pulsating electronic track that blends together elements of house and rock music. The song features a heavy bassline and driving percussion, with distorted guitar riffs and screaming vocals adding a rock edge to the mix. The song’s chorus, which repeatedly asks “Where’s your head at?” is instantly recognizable and has become a staple of the electronic dance music scene. “Where’s Your Head At?” is a high-energy track that is sure to get any dance floor moving, making it a classic in the world of electronic music.

35. Listen To Your Heart – D.H.T. feat. Edmee

“Listen To Your Heart” by D.H.T. featuring Edmee is a dance-pop cover of the classic 80s power ballad by Roxette. The song features a driving beat and pulsing synth lines, with Edmee’s powerful vocals delivering the emotional lyrics with conviction. The chorus soars with uplifting harmonies, encouraging listeners to follow their hearts and take chances in love. The song was a global hit, topping charts in several countries and earning widespread airplay on dance and pop radio stations. Its catchy melody and empowering message continue to resonate with listeners today.

36. Yeah Yeah – Bodyrox

“Yeah Yeah” by Bodyrox is an energetic dance track that’s sure to get your feet moving. The song features a catchy hook that’s easy to sing along to and a driving beat that keeps the energy high throughout. The lyrics encourage listeners to let go and enjoy the moment, creating a party atmosphere that’s perfect for a night out or a workout session. The production is sleek and polished, with layers of synths and percussion that create a dynamic and immersive sound. Overall, “Yeah Yeah” is a fun and infectious dance anthem that’s sure to get any crowd pumped up.

37. I Don’t Feel Like Dancin’ – Scissor Sisters

“I Don’t Feel Like Dancin'” is an infectious disco-pop anthem by American band Scissor Sisters. With its catchy chorus, vibrant horns, and pulsating beats, the song exudes a playful and energetic vibe that instantly gets you moving. The lyrics touch on the idea of not feeling up for a night out and just wanting to stay in, but ultimately giving in to the fun and dancing. Lead singer Jake Shears delivers an impressive vocal performance, adding an extra layer of passion and charm to the already lively tune. “I Don’t Feel Like Dancin'” is a timeless classic that remains a favorite among fans of disco and pop music alike.

38. Now You’re Gone – Basshunter

“Now You’re Gone” by Basshunter is an upbeat and infectious dance-pop song that became a massive hit in Europe and beyond. The song features a catchy melody and memorable chorus that is sure to get stuck in your head. The lyrics are about a lost love and the pain of being alone, but the upbeat tempo and electronic beats create a sense of hopefulness and energy. The song is characterized by its fast-paced rhythms, synthesizers, and pulsing basslines that give it a club-ready feel. Overall, “Now You’re Gone” is a perfect example of the power of dance music to unite people and bring joy to the dancefloor.

39. In For The Kill – La Roux

“In For The Kill” is a synth-pop and electroclash song by British artist La Roux. The track features driving synths and catchy hooks, with frontwoman Elly Jackson’s distinctive androgynous vocals delivering lyrics of desire and determination. The chorus is particularly infectious, with Jackson’s repeated assertion that she’s “going in for the kill” over a pulsing beat. The song became a hit in the UK and around the world, cementing La Roux’s status as a leading figure in the electro-pop revival of the late 2000s.

40. Keep Control – Sono

“Keep Control” is an electronic dance song by the German group Sono, released in 2001. The song features catchy and uplifting beats with a hypnotic and melodic chorus, creating a dancefloor anthem that still resonates with audiences today. The vocals are delivered in a deep, sultry tone that adds a layer of sensuality to the track. The lyrics, which speak to the importance of maintaining self-control, add a touch of emotional depth to the song. “Keep Control” is a classic example of the electro-house genre, and its enduring popularity is a testament to its timeless appeal.

41. Ooh La La – Goldfrapp

Goldfrapp’s “Ooh La La” is an energetic and sultry electronic dance-pop song that captivates the listeners with its seductive lyrics and infectious beat. The track starts with a synth riff and gradually builds up with the addition of electronic beats, guitars, and Alison Goldfrapp’s enchanting vocals. The chorus is a catchy and explosive explosion of sound that makes you want to move and dance along with it. The song is a perfect representation of the band’s unique sound and style, combining elements of electro-pop, glam rock, and disco to create a track that is both retro and contemporary at the same time.

42. As The Rush Comes – Motorcycle

“As The Rush Comes” by Motorcycle is a progressive trance track that features the soaring vocals of Jes Brieden. The song begins with a mellow, atmospheric intro before building to a pulsating beat and ethereal melody. The lyrics describe the feeling of being lost in the moment and the desire to hold onto that euphoria forever. The combination of Brieden’s haunting vocals and the hypnotic beat create a powerful and emotive listening experience. The song has become a trance classic and is often cited as one of the genre’s defining tracks.

43. Take Me Away – 4 Strings

“Take Me Away” is a euphoric trance anthem that features a dreamy female vocal and a driving beat that is sure to get anyone on the dance floor. The track begins with an atmospheric intro before building up to a euphoric drop that is sure to send chills down your spine. The lyrics speak to the desire to escape and be taken to a place where the worries of the world can be forgotten. With its infectious melody and powerful beat, “Take Me Away” is a timeless classic in the world of trance music that will leave you feeling uplifted and energized.

44. Losing My Edge – LCD Soundsystem

LCD Soundsystem’s “Losing My Edge” is a post-punk, electroclash, and dance-punk influenced track that was released in 2002. The song features James Murphy’s deadpan vocals over a frenetic beat, punctuated by glitchy electronic sounds and guitars. The lyrics center around Murphy’s fears of becoming outdated in the ever-changing music scene, and his desperate attempts to hold onto his edge. The track’s production is raw and gritty, with a lo-fi aesthetic that gives it a garage band feel. “Losing My Edge” has become a seminal track in the indie dance music scene and is often cited as a precursor to the hipster movement of the mid-2000s.

45. Idioteque – Radiohead

“Idioteque” is an electronic-driven song by British rock band Radiohead, featured on their critically acclaimed album “Kid A” released in 2000. The track’s haunting opening features a looped sample of someone counting down from ten in French, followed by a glitchy drum beat and distorted synthesizers. The song’s lyrics reflect a sense of societal and environmental decay, with themes of technology, global warming, and political unrest.

The vocal delivery by lead singer Thom Yorke is fragmented and eerie, adding to the song’s overall atmosphere. The chorus is anthemic, with Yorke repeating the refrain “Ice Age coming, Ice Age coming,” which could be interpreted as a warning of impending doom.

The song’s experimental sound, blending elements of electronic music with rock, garnered praise from critics and fans alike. It has been noted as a standout track from the album and a significant moment in Radiohead’s career. “Idioteque” has been covered and remixed by various artists and has become a fan favorite at live shows.

Overall, “Idioteque” is a haunting, thought-provoking song that showcases Radiohead’s willingness to experiment with their sound and tackle weighty subject matter. Its eerie and apocalyptic tone has made it a standout track in the band’s discography and a must-listen for fans of experimental music.

46. Blind – Hercules & Love Affair

“Blind” is a dance-pop song by American musical project Hercules & Love Affair, released in 2008. The song features guest vocals from Antony Hegarty, the lead singer of Antony and the Johnsons, whose unique voice adds a haunting quality to the track. The song’s instrumentation is driven by a funky bassline and a pulsing beat, overlaid with a melodic synthesizer riff.

The lyrics of “Blind” speak to themes of identity and self-discovery, with Antony delivering lines such as “I recognize myself in every stranger’s eyes” and “I am a child of the sun and sky.” The song’s chorus is infectious, with Antony singing the refrain “I’m blind” over and over again.

“Blind” received critical acclaim upon its release, with many praising the song’s unique blend of dance and pop sensibilities. The track has been remixed by various artists, including Frankie Knuckles and Hercules & Love Affair themselves, and has been featured in several films and television shows.

Overall, “Blind” is a catchy and thought-provoking dance-pop song that showcases the talents of both Hercules & Love Affair and Antony Hegarty. Its infectious chorus and funky instrumentation make it a standout track in the world of dance music, while its deeper themes give it a layer of depth that elevates it beyond typical club fare.

47. (This Is) The Dream Of Evan And Chan – Dntel

“(This Is) The Dream of Evan and Chan” is an indie electronic song by Dntel, the solo project of American musician Jimmy Tamborello. The track features vocals from Ben Gibbard, the lead singer of Death Cab for Cutie, and was originally released in 2002 as a single.

The song’s instrumentation is built around a catchy synth riff that ebbs and flows throughout the track, accompanied by a steady beat and various glitchy electronic effects. Gibbard’s vocals are tender and emotive, perfectly capturing the song’s dreamy atmosphere.

The lyrics of “(This Is) The Dream of Evan and Chan” speak to themes of longing and connection, with Gibbard singing lines such as “I’m reaching for the phone to call at 7:03 and on your machine I slur a plea for you to come home.” The song’s chorus is uplifting, with Gibbard repeating the refrain “This is the dream of Evan and Chan” over and over again.

The track has been remixed by various artists, including Superpitcher and Barbara Morgenstern, and has been featured in several films and television shows.

Overall, “(This Is) The Dream of Evan and Chan” is a beautiful and atmospheric indie electronic song that showcases Dntel’s talents as a producer and Ben Gibbard’s skills as a vocalist. Its dreamy instrumentation and heartfelt lyrics make it a standout track in the world of indie music, and its enduring popularity has cemented it as a classic of the genre.

48. Body Language – M.A.N.D.Y. vs Booka Shade

“Body Language” is a classic electronic dance track by the collaboration of M.A.N.D.Y. and Booka Shade. Released in 2005, the song features a hypnotic beat and a pulsing bassline that drive the track forward, creating an irresistible groove that is sure to get people on the dancefloor.

49. Tessio – Luomo

“Tessio” is an electronic dance track by Finnish producer Sasu Ripatti, who records under the name Luomo. Released in 2000, the song features a driving beat and a hypnotic bassline that create a sense of urgency and momentum.

The track’s title is derived from a character in the Italian novel “Il Gattopardo” by Giuseppe Tomasi di Lampedusa, and the song’s lyrics are sung in Italian, adding to its exotic and mysterious vibe.

“Tessio” is a masterclass in minimalism, with Ripatti making the most of just a few carefully crafted elements to create a track that is both hypnotic and infectious. Its use of electronic effects and vocal samples is subtle yet effective, adding to the overall sense of atmosphere and tension.

The song has been remixed and reworked by numerous artists, and has been featured in several films and television shows. Its enduring popularity is a testament to its hypnotic power and Ripatti’s talents as a producer.

Overall, “Tessio” is a standout electronic dance track that showcases the talents of Luomo. Its minimalist approach and use of electronic effects make it a classic of the genre, and its ability to create a sense of atmosphere and tension is a testament to Ripatti’s skills as a producer.

The production is simple but effective, with Armand Van Helden expertly layering various elements to create a dynamic and immersive sound. It has been remixed and sampled many times over the years, but the original version remains a timeless masterpiece in the electronic dance music canon.

86. Breathe – Telepopmusik

Telepopmusik’s “Breathe” is a mesmerizing downtempo electronic song that effortlessly combines ambient, trip-hop, and dream pop elements. The track’s haunting vocals, delivered by Angela McCluskey, float over a chilled-out beat and layers of atmospheric soundscapes. The lyrics speak of longing and introspection, with lines like “I brought you something close to me, left for something you see, my fears are lost and I can’t get even.” “Breathe” has a melancholic, yet uplifting quality that makes it perfect for introspective moments or late-night listening sessions. It’s no surprise that the song has become a cult classic in the electronic music scene.

87. Blind Faith – Chase & Status feat. Liam Bailey

“Blind Faith” is a pulsating drum and bass track by British duo Chase & Status, featuring the soulful vocals of Liam Bailey. The song opens with a somber piano melody before quickly building into a frenetic rhythm, with Bailey’s powerful voice soaring over the complex beats. The lyrics speak to the themes of faith and perseverance, urging the listener to keep moving forward even when faced with adversity. The track’s intense energy and emotional depth make it a standout in the drum and bass genre, with a sound that is both hard-hitting and deeply emotive.

88. Emerge – Fischerspooner

Fischerspooner’s “Emerge” is an electronic dance track that combines elements of electroclash, synth-pop, and new wave. The song’s distinctive synth riff and pulsing beat, along with Casey Spooner’s deadpan vocals, create an atmosphere of detached coolness and futuristic energy. The lyrics suggest a desire to escape mundane reality and “emerge” into a more exciting, alternative world of possibility. “Emerge” was a breakout hit for Fischerspooner and helped establish the group as one of the pioneers of the electroclash movement in the early 2000s.

89. Eple – Royksopp

“Eple” by Röyksopp is an electronic music track that combines elements of ambient and downtempo genres with glitchy beats and a playful melody. The song opens with a dreamy synth sequence that gradually builds up to a rhythmic beat, with glitchy sounds and cut-up vocals adding to the track’s unique character. As the song progresses, layers of textures and melodies are introduced, creating a rich and intricate sonic landscape. “Eple” is a catchy and hypnotic track that showcases Röyksopp’s talent for crafting intricate electronic music that is both experimental and accessible.

90. Strict Machine – Goldfrapp

“Strict Machine” is a captivating electronic dance track by British duo Goldfrapp. Released in 2003, the song features Alison Goldfrapp’s sensual vocals over a pulsating synth-pop beat. The lyrics are evocative and seductive, drawing the listener in with lines like “I’m an angel with a shotgun, fighting ’til the war’s won.” The track’s production is polished and expertly crafted, with layers of electronic sounds and a driving bassline that create an irresistible groove. “Strict Machine” is a standout hit from Goldfrapp’s critically acclaimed album “Black Cherry” and remains a beloved favorite in the electronic music scene.

91. Satellite – OceanLab

“Satellite” is a trance anthem that showcases the ethereal vocals of Justine Suissa and the mesmerizing production of Above & Beyond’s OceanLab project. The track starts with atmospheric synths and a steady beat, gradually building up to a euphoric chorus with soaring melodies and Suissa’s captivating voice. The lyrics speak of longing and distance, with the narrator yearning to connect with someone who seems too far away. “Satellite” is a perfect example of uplifting trance, with its infectious energy and emotional resonance making it a favorite among fans of the genre.

92. Flight 643 – Tiesto

“Flight 643” is a progressive trance track by Dutch DJ and producer Tiesto. Released in 2001, it features an energetic and driving beat that builds throughout the track, with a dramatic breakdown and a soaring synth melody. The track was a major hit in the trance music scene, cementing Tiesto’s status as one of the genre’s most influential artists. The title is a reference to Tiesto’s frequent touring, with 643 being the flight number of his regular journey from Amsterdam to New York. The track is a classic example of Tiesto’s signature sound, combining melody, energy, and emotion to create an unforgettable dancefloor experience.

93. No One On Earth – Above & Beyond

“No One on Earth” is a trance anthem produced by Above & Beyond, featuring the angelic vocals of Zoë Johnston. The track captures the emotion and euphoria of a transcendent moment on the dancefloor. The combination of Zoë’s ethereal voice and the uplifting melodies build to an epic climax that leaves the listener with a sense of wonder and awe. With its unforgettable hook and soaring synths, “No One on Earth” is a classic example of Above & Beyond’s signature sound and a testament to their status as one of the most beloved and influential acts in trance music.

94. La La Land – Green Velvet

“La La Land” by Green Velvet is an upbeat, funky electronic dance track that’s impossible not to move to. The song’s catchy vocal samples are layered over a driving beat, punctuated by bursts of synths and a bouncing bassline. With its high energy and infectious rhythm, “La La Land” is a classic example of Green Velvet’s signature sound, blending elements of techno, house, and funk to create a sound that’s entirely his own. The song’s playful lyrics and irreverent attitude add to its charm, making it a favorite among fans of electronic dance music around the world.

95. Rippin Kittin – Golden Boy & Miss Kittin

“Rippin Kittin” is a mesmerizing electronic track with vocals by the French singer Miss Kittin and produced by English musician Golden Boy. Released in 2002, the song combines elements of electroclash and techno, creating an infectious beat that hooks the listener from the very first note. Miss Kittin’s vocals are sultry and seductive, adding a layer of sensuality to the already hypnotic melody. The lyrics describe a toxic relationship between two people who can’t seem to resist each other despite the harm it causes. “Rippin Kittin” has become a classic in the electronic music scene, known for its catchy melody and iconic vocals.

96. Propane Nightmares – Pendulum

“Propane Nightmares” is a high-energy drum and bass track by Australian electronic music group Pendulum. It features a powerful and intricate drum pattern, heavy basslines, and a soaring vocal chorus. The song has a sense of urgency and momentum that keeps building throughout, with intense drops and breaks that will make you want to move. The lyrics evoke a sense of adventure and a journey into the unknown, with references to dreams and hallucinations. Overall, “Propane Nightmares” is a thrilling and dynamic piece of music that showcases Pendulum’s skillful blend of electronic and rock influences.

97. Scary Monsters And Nice Sprites – Skrillex

“Scary Monsters and Nice Sprites” is a high-energy, dubstep track by Skrillex that has become an iconic part of the genre. The song opens with eerie, otherworldly vocals before launching into a flurry of bass drops and glitchy synth riffs. The intense, driving beat is contrasted with moments of relative calm, making for a dynamic listening experience. The track is characterized by its heavy use of wobble bass and aggressive sound design, which give it a distinctly futuristic and experimental feel. “Scary Monsters and Nice Sprites” is a must-listen for fans of electronic music and dubstep in particular.

98. The Sky Was Pink – Nathan Fake

“The Sky Was Pink” by Nathan Fake is an electronic dance track that builds on a mesmerizing melody, trippy synths, and a deep bassline that hooks the listener from the start. The song starts with a slow and ethereal intro that gradually builds up into a hypnotic beat that gets more complex and layered as it progresses. The use of distortion, delay, and reverb effects give the track a surreal and dreamy quality that perfectly complements the overall vibe. With its immersive soundscapes and intricate production, “The Sky Was Pink” showcases Nathan Fake’s talent as an electronic music composer and producer.

99. Easy Lee – Ricardo Villalobos

“Easy Lee” by Ricardo Villalobos is a captivating techno track that’s characterized by its rhythmic bassline and intricate percussive elements. The song starts off with a repetitive bassline that gradually becomes more complex as the track progresses, building up tension until the beat drops. The percussive elements are the standout feature of the track, with various intricate patterns layered on top of each other to create a dense, textured soundscape. There are also some subtle melodic elements that add to the overall atmosphere of the track. “Easy Lee” is a perfect example of Villalobos’ skillful production techniques and his ability to create immersive, hypnotic techno tracks.

100. He Not In – Chicken Lips

“He Not In” is an electro-house track by British electronic music group Chicken Lips, released in 2003. The song features a steady, pulsing beat and a catchy vocal hook that repeats throughout the track. The song’s minimalistic approach to production, with stripped-back instrumentation and a focus on groove, helped make it a club classic and a favorite of DJs. The track’s funky bassline and infectious melody make it a great example of the type of dance music that was popular in the early 2000s. “He Not In” remains a timeless dance floor filler that still receives regular play in clubs today.
